I really like Dave Rubin and respect him for sharing how his mind has been changed about abortion (moving from permissible at 20 to now at 12 weeks). He states that "if you care about individual rights, what you have to first care about is the woman in the here and now" (59:47). To me that sounds like operating on a system of degrees of personhood which is a very hard road to walk down. What makes a human a person is not dependent on anything like size, environment (in the womb), development or dependency. It's inherent from the moment of conception. You don't get the right to kill someone just because you're bigger than someone else. This quote from Lincoln is a good representation of how dangerous this relative state of being can be. Just replace the word "white" and "black" with small/unborn or big/born, and "enslave" with abort.

"You say A. is white, and B. is black. It is color, then; the lighter, having the right to enslave the darker? Take care. By this rule, you are to be slave to the first man you meet, with a fairer skin than your own. You do not mean color exactly?--You mean the whites are intellectually the superiors of the blacks, and, therefore have the right to enslave them? Take care again. By this rule, you are to be slave to the first man you meet, with an intellect superior to your own. But, say you, it is a question of interest; and, if you can make it your interest, you have the right to enslave another. Very well. And if he can make it his interest, he has the right
to enslave you."

A fascinating conversation.  It is so rare these days to hear thoughtful, reasoned dialogue.  On the topic of abortion I am impressed that Dave is open to ideas from other perspectives.  I asked my sister (a nurse) the following question:  If a woman goes to her doctor and asks for a foot amputation would the doctor agree to it?  My sister said "No" if the foot is healthy.  So a woman or any person doesn't have the right to do "anything" with his or her own body.  There are limits.
Well if the woman really wanted her foot amputated she would just do it herself. Just like an abortion a women would just do it herself. Ever heard of back ally abortions?
Great point!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  Never thought of it before but it should be reposted on other forums too

@Andrew Camacho Tough questions for sure.  Here in Australia it's not such a fevered argument as it seems to be in the USA.  People here take both sides of the argument but we don't have angry demos in the streets about it.

I realize the analogy isn't perfect but the point is: Does a person have an absolute right to do anything to his or her body? "It's my body, isn't it?"

Another point cold be: every part of you body has your DNA. A fetus has half of your DNA. The fetus is in your body but is not your body. I know it sounds weird but I believe science backs it up. However I reserve the right to be completely wrong.

Your foot analogy is quite interesting, but I'm not sure it is an equivalent argument. Chopping off a healthy foot would leave the woman with a permanent physical disability. Terminating a fetus would not. You could argue about the mental side of things, but physically, the woman would be as healthy as before.  So I'm not sure how you bring 'rights' into this analogy...

@Sic Semper Tyrannis Look, I think you are getting the wrong impression here. I am assuming your position is based on a general distrust of state power and a desire to resist or reject any attempt by the state to extend its powers. I am sympathetic to that. I too think we must all be cautious about the overreach of state power. We have seen governments all over the West extend their powers under the guise of "anti-terrorism" and now we are seeing a further extension of state power in response to the coronavirus. However, authoritarianism is not left or right. It is its own parameter and has historically been supported at various points by both left wing and right wing governments. At present, the increase in state power in the US is happening under the Republican Party, and in the UK it is happening under the Conservative Party. Despite this, I still do not find comparisons to extreme totalitarian societies constructive for the specific example you gave in your original comment.

As for the opposition to free speech that seems to be a problem among today's liberals, yes, that is also an issue and something which should not be underestimated. However, the divisions in today's society cannot wholly be pinned on the left. The issue is tribalism and a breakdown of genuine discussion in general. This seems to be a bigger problem in the US than it is in the UK.
